name: Amy Winehouse
description:
'''Amy Jade Winehouse''' (14 September 1983 – 23 July 2011) was a British singer, songwriter, musician and businesswoman. She is known for her distinctive [[contralto]] vocals, expressive and [[autobiographical]] songwriting, and eclectic blend of genres such as [[rhythm and blues]], [[Soul music|soul]], and [[jazz]]. Her music, fashion and highly publicised personal life made her an [[Amy Winehouse in popular culture|influential figure in popular culture]].

Born to a Jewish family in [[Enfield, London]], Winehouse grew up in a jazz-influenced household. She was a member of the [[National Youth Jazz Orchestra]] in her youth, recording several songs before signing a publishing deal with [[EMI]]. After a friend passed her demo to a music executive, Winehouse signed with [[Island Records]] in 2002. Her debut studio album, ''[[Frank (Amy Winehouse album)|Frank]]'' (2003), was commercially successful in the UK and drew critical acclaim for its mature songwriting and jazz-imbued production. Its lead single, "[[Stronger Than Me]]", earned the singer an [[Ivor Novello Award]].

Winehouse's second studio album, ''[[Back to Black]]'' (2006), was an international critical and commercial success, and became one of the [[List of best-selling albums|best-selling albums of all time]]. Its lead single, "[[Rehab (Amy Winehouse song)|Rehab]]", was a worldwide top-ten song and won her a second Ivor Novello Award. At the [[50th Annual Grammy Awards]] in 2008, Winehouse won five awards, tying the then-[[Grammy Award records#Most Grammys won by a female artist in one night|record for the most Grammys won by a female artist in a single night]] and becoming the first British woman to win five Grammys. Her wins included three of the "[[Big Four (Grammy Awards)|Big Four]]" categories—[[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]], and [[Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]] and [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]] for "Rehab"—along with [[Best Pop Vocal Album]].

Winehouse's career was often overshadowed by [[substance abuse]], mental illness, and addiction, culminating in her death from [[alcohol poisoning]] at her [[Camden Square]] home in London at the [[27 Club|age of 27]]. Her brother believed that [[bulimia]] was also a factor. Winehouse's life and career were depicted in the documentary [[Amy (2015 film)|''Amy'']] (2015) and dramatised in the biopic ''[[Back to Black (film)|Back to Black]]'' (2024). Publications such as ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' and [[VH1]] have ranked her amongst the greatest artists in history. In 2025, ''Back to Black'' was preserved in the [[National Recording Registry]] by the [[Library of Congress]].
